hedline.hl1: A VCR That Won't Accept Peanut Butter and Jelly

abstract.p: Sony Electronics offers videocassette recorder with tape slot that can belocked to keep out wayward objects and timer to enable parent to limit amount of tape viewing; photo (S)

block.p: A videocassette recorder and a child can be a hazardous combination -- for the VCR. The tape slot has been known to attract foreign objects, including the occasional peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Sony Electronics has introduced a new machine with a tape slot that can be locked to keep wayward objects out.

A videocassette recorder and a child can be a hazardous combination -- for the VCR. The tape slot has been known to attract foreign objects, including the occasional peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Sony Electronics has introduced a new machine with a tape slot that can be locked to keep wayward objects out.

The new model, called the MovieTime and priced at $99, also has a timer so that parents can limit the amount of tape viewing at one sitting. For children who can't stand dead air, the machine displays animation while a tape is being fast-forwarded or rewound. One other parent-friendly feature: the Eject button locks, so even if Junior is sick of seeing that old Barney tape, he can't opt out.
